title: Denver music community rallies around Tennis drummer

DENVER – A well-known local musician who admits that he prefers being behind the scenes helping out is now front and center … and in need of the help that he usually gives. 
Joe Richmond (Photo: Courtesy Nate Meese) 
Joe Richmond, who has lent his drumming skills to D 
enver bands Meese, Churchill and Tennis, has what he calls a "hole in his foot" after a motorcycle accident on Oct. 10. When he was getting treatment, he found out he had been dropped from his insurance – leaving him with hefty medical bills. 
But thanks to the support of the Denver music scene, Richmond, who had to cancel his appearance playing in Tennis' national tour opening for Shakey Graves, is on his way to getting back on his feet (literally). 
"I just can't even believe all of the people that have come out to support me in this time … and I'm just incredibly grateful," Richmond said. 
As of Tuesday evening, friends and strangers had donated almost $15,000 to a GoFundMe page set up by Richmond's girlfriend . Wednesday night, they'll gather at Syntax Physic Opera on South Broadway from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. for a fundraiser in his honor. 
"I definitely want to come out and see the few people that support me," Richmond said, admitting that because of his injury, he doesn't know how long he'll stay out. 
"My friends and the music community have been pretty incredible and helpful in this time, where I'm just kind of hard up, and realizing that this is going to be a big uphill battle," he said. 
Richmond has called the entire experience "incredibly humbling." 
"I realize everyone has their own things, and life happens to everybody," he said. "Just the fact that they care to take the time and energy to help out – it's incredible."
